title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text:
3 Phases of Data


Raw data may be original data that you collected It may be externally collected data that you extracted from a site or received from a partner Here I just simply mean you have conducted no transformations on the data

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text:
A Sampling of Open Datasets








What do you notice when you look at these different datasets?
There is no real consistency in how data is structured, variables are named, o
Adhering to common standards for data quality allows our data to be consistently cleaned and organized within and across projects. There are several data quality criteria that are commonly agreed upon

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text:
Learning Objectives


Understand how to assess a data set for 7 data quality indicators



Be able to review a data set and apply a list of standardized data cleaning steps as needed



Feel comfortable using R code to clean a data set using our standardized steps



Understand types of documentation that should be shared alongside data



Before cleaning our data, we need to have a shared understanding for what we expect our data to look like once it is cleaned.

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text: The Data are Ready

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text:
7 Data Quality Indicators




Analyzable
Interpretable
Complete
Valid
Accurate
Consistent
De-identified





Taming the Data Beast, by Allison Horst

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text:
Analyzable

Data should make a rectangle of rows and columns

The first row, and only the first row, is your variable names
The remaining data should be made up of values in cells
At least one column uniquely defines the rows in the data (e.g., unique identifier)

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text:
Analyzable

Column values are analyzable

Information is explicit

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text: Analyzable

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text:
Analyzable

Only one piece of information is collected per variable

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text:
Exercise

What data quality issues do you detect for the ‚Äúanalyzable‚Äù indicator?




‚àí+
01:00

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text:
Solution

Data does not make a rectangle
Color coding used to convey information
More than one piece of information in a variable
Blank values implied to be 0 for Q4 variables

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text:
Interpretable



Variable names should be machine-readable

Unique
No spaces or special characters except _

This includes no . or -

Not begin with a number

Variable names should be human-readable

Meaningful (gender instead of Q1)
Consistently formatted (capitalization and delimiters)
Consistent order of information

w1_t_mast1, w1_t_mast2, w1_t_gad1, w1_t_gad2, w1_t_gender







In that case, by Allison Horst

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text:
Interpretable

If you are sharing data in SPSS, SAS, or Stata format, you may consider adding embedded metadata (i.e., variable label and value labels)

When publicly sharing data, it is recommended to share data in at least one non-proprietary format (e.g., CSV)

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text:
Exercise

What data quality issues do you detect for the ‚Äúinterpretable‚Äù indicator?




‚àí+
01:00

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text:
Solution

Spaces and special characters used in variable names
Some variable names are unclear
Inconsistent use of capitalization

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text:
Complete

Cases

The number of rows in your dataset should total to your sample N

No missing cases
No duplicate cases (i.e., no unique identifier)


Variables

The number of columns in your dataset should total to what you planned to have

No missing variables

No unexpected missing data

If you collected the data, it should exist in the dataset

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text:
Helpful documentation
Tracking Database





Data Dictionary

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text:
Exercise

What data quality issues do you detect for the ‚Äúcomplete‚Äù indicator?




‚àí+
01:00

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text:
Solution

The data contain a duplicate ID (104)

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text:
Valid

Variables conform to your planned constraints (i.e., review your data dictionary)

Planned variable types (e.g., numeric, character, date)
Allowable variable values and ranges (e.g., 1-5)
Item-level missingness aligns with variable universe rules and skip patterns

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text: Helpful documentation

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text:
Exercise

What data quality issues do you detect for the ‚Äúvalid‚Äù indicator?




‚àí+
01:00

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text:
Solution

AGE/YR does not adhere to our planned variable type
Values in Score fall out of our expected range

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text:
Accurate

Information should be accurate based on any implicit knowledge you have

For instance, values should not exist for a school where you know that data was not collected that wave

Accurate within and across sources

A date of birth collected from school records should match the date of birth provided by the student
If a student is in 2nd grade, they should be associated with a second grade teacher

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text:
Exercise

What data quality issues do you detect for the ‚Äúaccurate‚Äù indicator?




‚àí+
01:00

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text:
Solution

ID 105 has conflicting information for TEACHING LEVEL and SCHOOL

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text:
Consistent

Variable values are consistently measured, formatted, or categorized within a column
Variables are consistently measured across collections of the same form

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text:
Exercise

What data quality issues do you detect for the ‚Äúconsistent‚Äù indicator?




‚àí+
01:00

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text:
Solution

Values for GENDER are not consistently categorized

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text: De-identified

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text:
De-identified - Indirect Identifiers

Open-ended questions

These variables may contain information that can directly or indirectly identify individuals.

Outliers

If someone has extreme values for a variable, it may be easier to identify that individual.

Small cell sizes

NCES Standard 4-2-10, suggests that all categories have at least 3 cases to minimize risk

Combinations of variables, or crosstabs, can also create small cell-sizes

race + gender + grade level

Also consider what other public information could be used to re-identify someone

Linking department of education data with your data (e.g., by size and location of school)



You also need to consider all of this in the context of risk. So if you are collecting information that is fairly innocuous (like maybe it‚Äôs a math assessment), the risk of harm if your re-identified is pretty low. If you are collecting information like, how often do you use drugs, the risk is higher because that information could impact your career, relationships, and so forth.

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text:
Exercise

What data quality issues do you detect for the ‚Äúde-identified‚Äù indicator?




‚àí+
01:00

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text:
Solution

Replace School Name with an unique ID
Review combination of demographics to see if other alterations are necessary



That one PhD may or may not be an issue. May there is only one person with a PhD in our sample, but many with PhDs in the school so maybe it‚Äôs not a big deal. People (outside of that school) don‚Äôt necessarily know who is in our sample and who is not.

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text:
Biggest Advice
The number one way to reduce data errors is to make a plan before you collect data

Correct data at the source




Plan the variables you want to collect




Build your data collection/entry tools in a way that follows your plan




Test your data tools before collecting/entering data




Check your data often during data collection/entry

 Review the raw data
 Find missing data
 Adjust the sample
 De-identify data
 Drop irrelevant columns
 Split columns
 Rename variables
 Normalize variables
 Standardize variables

 Update variable types
 Recode variables
 Construct new variables
 Add missing values
 Add metadata
 Validate data
 Join data
 Reshape data
 Save clean data

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text:
Data validation



Complete

Check for missing/duplicate cases

Check Ns by groups for completeness

Correct for missing/too many columns

Valid and consistent

Check for unallowed categories/values out of range

Check ranges by groups

Check for invalid, non-unique, or missing study IDs
Check for incorrect variable types/formats
Check missing value patterns




Accurate

Agreement across variables

De-identified

All direct identifiers are removed
All indirect identifiers managed as needed

Interpretable

Variables correctly named

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text:
Packages

R has many built in (base) functions
We can also use functions that live in packages that we can install onto our computer
Once installed, there are two ways to call packages

You may see both methods used in these slides





Using library()

library(dplyr)

mtcars |>  
  select(mpg, cyl) 


Using Namespacing package::function()

# library(dplyr) not needed

mtcars |>  
  dplyr::select(mpg, cyl)

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text:
Tidyverse

An opinionated collection of R packages designed for data science
All packages share an underlying design philosophy, grammar, and data structures

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text:
Tidyverse

Selecting test_score and grade_level from our data frame named sch_data



Tidy Evaluation


select(sch_data, test_score, 
       grade_level)

# A tibble: 2 x 2
  test_score grade_level
       <dbl>       <dbl>
1          3         380
2        290           3



Base R


sch_data[ , c("test_score", 
              "grade_level")]

# A tibble: 2 x 2
  test_score grade_level
       <dbl>       <dbl>
1          3         380
2        290           3

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text:
Pipes

2014+ magrittr pipe %>%
2021+ (R \(\geq\) 4.1.0) native R pipe |>


Isabella Vel√°squez‚Äôs blog post Understanding the native R pipe |> (2022)






sch_data <- select(sch_data, id, 
                    test_score)

sch_data <- filter(sch_data, 
                    test_score > 300)



sch_data <- sch_data |>
  select(id, test_score) |>
  filter(test_score > 300)






To turn on the native pipe:
Tools ‚Üí Global Options ‚Üí Code ‚Üí Editing ‚Üí Use Native Pipe Operator

Review our data



How many rows?

In this hypothetical situation, we assume we are not missing any cases
However, there may be duplicates

How many columns?

Compare to our data dictionary

What are the variable values and ranges?

Compare to our data dictionary

How much missing data do we have?


There are several functions we can use to explore data

dplyr::glimpse()
skimr::skim()
base::summary()
summarytools::dfSummary()
Hmisc::describe()

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text:
Adjust the sample

There are two key functions we can use to both identify and remove duplicates in our data

janitor::get_dupes()

Tells you which rows contain duplicate unique identifiers, if any

dplyr::distinct()

Keeps the first instance of a duplicate unique identifier

But what if your raw data is sorted differently at a later point?
Helpful to use dplyr::arrange() first so that your data is always sorted the same way before dropping your duplicates

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text:
Adjust the sample


Check for duplicates

df |>
  get_dupes(id_vars)


Replace ‚Äúid_vars‚Äù with your unique identifier
If you have more than one variable that uniquely identifies rows, use c(id1, id2)


Remove duplicates

df |>
  arrange(another_identier) |>
  distinct(id_vars, 
           .keep_all = TRUE)


Replace ‚Äúanother_identifier‚Äù with a variable that makes your duplicates unique (e.g., ‚Äúdate‚Äù)
Replace ‚Äúid_vars‚Äù with your unique identifier/s
Always add the argument ‚Äú.keep_all = TRUE‚Äù

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text:
Exercise

Navigate to exercise 3.
Run the code to check for duplicates.

Which tch_id is duplicated?

Our documented rule is that if both surveys are complete, keep the most recently completed row.

Run the code to check for duplicates again.

Are the duplicates removed?

Run the code to confirm that we kept the most recent submission of the duplicate survey (‚Äú2023-04-02‚Äù).




‚àí+
05:00

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text:
De-identify data

The functions used here will depend on what is required.
Examples of functions you might use:

dplyr::select() to drop variables
dplyr::case_when() or dplyr::recode() to collapse categories/recode values
dplyr::*_join() to merge in identifying variables
stringr::str_remove() or stringr::str_replace() to redact character values


Here we are going to use dplyr::select() and dplyr::case_when()

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text:
De-identify data

Select or Drop Variables


To select variables of interest

df |>
  select(varname1, varname2, varname3)


To drop variables I add -

df |>
  select(-varname1)


If I had more than one variable to drop, I can use -c(var1, var2)

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text:
De-identify data
Recategorize Values


Recategorize numeric values

df |>
  dplyr::mutate(new_var_name =
                  case_when(
                    var_name == old_value ~ new_value,
                    var_name == old_value ~ new_value,
                  ))


Recategorize character values

df |>
  dplyr::mutate(new_var_name =
                  case_when(
                    var_name %in% c("geom", "alg") ~ "math",
                    var_name %in% c("lit", "read") ~ "ela"
                  ))




To learn more about setting default values for case_when(), type ?case_when in your console
Note that there is a new function, case_match(), that is worth looking in to. It reduces repetition in the syntax.

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text:
Rename variables
Two functions we can use to rename variables

dplyr::rename()

Commonly used to rename just a few variables

purrr::set_names()

Used to rename all of our variables
Variables must be in the exact right order





Rename one variable

df |>
  rename(new_name = old_name)


Rename all variables

df |>
  set_names(c("name1", "name2", "name3"))

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text:
Exercise

Take 3 minutes to rename variables

Navigate to exercise 3.
Review the current variable names.
Rename variables according to our data dictionary.
Check variable names again to make sure the renaming worked.




‚àí+
03:00

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text:
Normalize variables
There are several functions that can help us remove unexpected values from our variables.
Some examples of those include:

stringr::str_remove_all()
stringr::str_replace_all()
readr::parse_number()


Say this is our data


# A tibble: 3 x 2
     id income 
  <dbl> <chr>  
1     1 $32,000
2     2 120000 
3     3 $45,000

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text:
Normalize variables



Remove character values with stringr::str_remove_all()

df |>
  dplyr::mutate(income = 
                  str_remove_all(income, "\\$|,"))

# A tibble: 3 x 2
     id income
  <dbl> <chr> 
1     1 32000 
2     2 120000
3     3 45000 



Notice that our variable is still character type


Remove character values with readr::parse_number()

df |>
  dplyr::mutate(income = 
                  parse_number(income))

# A tibble: 3 x 2
     id income
  <dbl>  <dbl>
1     1  32000
2     2 120000
3     3  45000



Notice that parse_number() converts our variable to numeric type

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text:
Exercise

Take 3 minutes to normalize our tch_yrs variable

Navigate to exercise 6.
Review the current values for tch_yrs.
Remove all non-numeric values from this variable.
Review the new values in tch_yrs.




‚àí+
03:00

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text:
Update variable type
Depending on what is needed, there are several functions we can use to change variable types.
Some examples include:

as.numeric()
as.character()
as.Date()
Several functions in the lubridate package to assist with converting dates
janitor::excel_numeric_to_date() can be very helpful at times

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text:
Update variable type
It‚Äôs important to normalize variables before converting types (especially when converting from character to numeric)



Our data without normalizing

df

# A tibble: 3 x 2
     id income 
  <dbl> <chr>  
1     1 $32,000
2     2 120000 
3     3 $45,000



When we try to convert income to numeric‚Ä¶.

df |>
  dplyr::mutate(income = 
                  as.numeric(income))

Warning in mask$eval_all_mutate(quo): NAs introduced by coercion


# A tibble: 3 x 2
     id income
  <dbl>  <dbl>
1     1     NA
2     2 120000
3     3     NA


We end up converting several values to NA (notice our warning)

title: Pre-work
text:
A portion of this workshop will be conducted in the Posit Cloud environment. Posit Cloud allows us all to work in the exact same environment with the same version of R, R packages, and directory of files. .
Please create a login to the Posit Cloud instance of this workshop here:
https://posit.cloud/content/7872027
Alternative
If you are struggling using Posit Cloud, you can download the materials locally on your machine.
Note that the presenter will NOT be able to help you with local computer problems during the workshop. To do this you will need the following to do the following prior to the workshop:
pkgs <- c("tidyverse", "readxl", "summarytools", "janitor")

install.packages(pkgs)
# install.packages("usethis")
usethis::use_course(
    "https://github.com/Cghlewis/ncme-data-cleaning-workshop/raw/main/exercises/exercises.zip",
    destdir = "___")

title: Pre-work
text:
R and RStudio
For this workshop it is assumed that you are comfortable navigating the RStudio environment and that you have some understanding of things like packages, functions, objects, and R syntax. If you need any refreshers, I recommend reviewing the following materials.

Getting Started with R

What They Forgot to Teach You About R (In particular, the ‚ÄúA holistic workflow‚Äù section)
R and Tidyverse for working with data
R Software Handbook

title: Pre-work
text:
Tidyverse
If you‚Äôre new to the {tidyverse}, here are some materials I recommend reviewing before the workshop.

R for Data Science
Tidyverse Skills for Data Science

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text:
Learning objectives

Understand how to assess a data set for 8 data quality indicators
Be able to review a data set and apply a list of standardized data cleaning steps as needed
Feel comfortable using R code to clean a data set
Understand types of documentation that should be shared alongside data

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text:
Is this workshop for me?
This workshop is for any education researcher who could benefit from guidance on how to take a messy raw dataset and organize it into a shareable data product.
This workshop assumes you have some experience working with rectangular data, as well as a basic working knowledge of the R programming language and experience working in RStudio. This course will focus on functions in the {Tidyverse} so familiarity with that package will be helpful, but is not required.

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text:
Further Reading

Data Management in Large-Scale Education Research book
Data Management for Data Sharing Blog Post Series
The Basics of Data Management
R Resources

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text:
Speaker
 Crystal Lewis is an independent research data management consultant, providing recommendations, direct service, and training to education researchers and their teams across the country. She also co-organizes two community groups‚ÄîR-Ladies St.¬†Louis, an organization focused on promoting gender diversity in the R community, as well as the POWER (providing women opportunities in education research) Data Management Hub, where she facilitates peer data management support in the education research community.
